content: The Act titled "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" allows for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The Act "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches for trainees. Eligible community colleges are defined as public higher education institutions. The Act authorizes quarterly payments to eligible community colleges for new manufacturing job training. Eligible colleges offer 2-year associate's degrees and participate in State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit programs. State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program is established by a State government for eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for eligible trainees, where the employer withholds State income taxes for the trainee's employment costs. The State's new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible manufacturing employers to sign a contract with eligible trainees. The employer withholds State income taxes for the trainee's employment costs, which are then remitted to the eligible community college as payment for education provided. The State's new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible manufacturing employers to sign a contract with eligible community colleges. The employer withholds State income taxes for the trainee's employment costs, which are then remitted to the college as payment for education provided. The amounts remitted will be treated as payment for education and as if they had been remitted to the State in payment of income taxes owed by the trainee. The contract between an eligible community college and a manufacturing employer in the State must meet all applicable requirements under the State program. The college will provide qualified training to designated individuals without charging tuition or fees. The employer or a qualified training provider will train designated individuals without charging tuition. The employer must hire these individuals for full-time employment at a State job site, paying them a wage of at least 175% of the Federal minimum wage or the State program amount. The employer must pay a wage of at least 175% of the Federal minimum wage or the State program amount. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for training costs specified in the contract. For qualified training under this section, the employer must pay a wage of at least 175% of the Federal minimum wage or the State program amount. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for the specified training costs. The contract must specify the entire cost of training, including equipment and materials, and the cost and terms must be reasonable by market standards. Qualified training provides education or skills necessary for the job the individual will be employed in. Qualified training, as defined in this section, includes education or training that equips an individual with the necessary skills for their job, required licenses, or certifications mandated by government regulations. Qualified training includes education or training that equips an individual with necessary skills, licenses, or certifications required for their job. A State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program must ensure that employers demonstrate the need for new jobs to participate. To qualify for a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program, employers must show that eligible trainees are hired for new jobs, not recalled, replacement, or existing ones within the past year. To qualify for a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program, employers must hire eligible trainees for new positions that result in a net increase in employment for the employer. Only U.S. employees are considered for this program. The State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program requires employers to hire eligible trainees for new positions that result in a net increase in employment for the employer. Only U.S. employees are considered for this program, and aggregation rules apply for determining eligibility. The State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows employers to hire eligible trainees for new positions, with aggregation rules applying to determine eligibility. Employers can collaborate with local workforce investment boards to find individuals to hire and train through the program. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 allows employers to hire and train eligible trainees through the State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program. Eligible trainees must have received qualified training from an eligible community college and be employed full-time by the employer who was part of the training contract. The term "eligible manufacturing employer" refers to a person who employs individuals in manufacturing within the United States. The employer must hire trainees from eligible community colleges for new jobs that meet specific requirements. The term "eligible manufacturing employer" refers to a person who employs individuals in manufacturing within the United States, with manufacturing facilities located in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the NAICS. Appropriations are made from the Treasury to support this section, and remission of State income tax withholdings for training or education is facilitated for eligible employers. The remission of State income tax withholdings for training or education by eligible manufacturing employers to community colleges is not considered as payments for training or education. The withheld State income tax amount is treated as if it had been remitted to the State in payment of income taxes owed by the employee. The withheld State income tax amount is treated as if it had been remitted to the State in payment of income taxes owed by the employee. In the case of an eligible trainee, the withheld State income tax and any payments made shall not be treated as income for the trainee under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amounts remitted for State income taxes by the employer on behalf of the trainee will be treated as amounts paid for State income taxes by the trainee for deduction purposes.
